newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa's police minister in row over undue force.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa's police minister in row over undue force.

text.p: South Africa's police minister was verbally abused by a policeman when the minister tried to stop the manhandling of a rape suspect being arrested, police said on Thursday.

Sydney Mufamadi, the country's first black police minister, was appointed by President Nelson Mandela three years ago to transform the image of the former white-led police force into a community-friendly service.
The usually unassuming minister was on his way to a shop to buy newspapers when he stumbled across the arrest on Saturday night in Johannesburg's Joubert Park, an inner city flatland.
"In the opinion of the minister, excessive force was being used against the suspect and he objected strenuously," said the office of the national police chief, George Fivaz.
"A verbal exchange then took place between the minister and the reservist in question," the office said in a statement.
Internal departmental charges are now being investigated against the policeman, a reservist.
The charges are for unbecoming conduct and excessive use of force towards the rape suspect. The police chief's office said that if proven, the policeman could also face criminal action.
